article.title: Excitonic linewidth approaching the homogeneous limit in MoS2 based van der Waals heterostructures : accessing spin-valley dynamics

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of encapsulating a MoS2 monolayer (ML) in hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) as shown in Figure 1a?
choices: Enhancement of charged exciton emission.
Significant reduction of the optical transition linewidth.
Increase in defect-related emission.
Shift of the neutral exciton emission to higher energies.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1b compares the photoluminescence (PL) spectra of capped and uncapped MoS2 MLs. What can be concluded from the difference in their linewidths?
choices: Capped MLs exhibit a significantly narrower linewidth, indicating higher optical quality.
Uncapped MLs show a narrower linewidth, suggesting stronger quantum confinement effects.
Both capped and uncapped MLs exhibit similar linewidths, indicating negligible influence of hBN.
The linewidth difference is solely due to differences in the substrate material.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1d illustrates the temperature dependence of the neutral exciton linewidth in a capped MoS2 ML. What is the dominant broadening mechanism at low temperatures?
choices: Interaction with optical phonons.
Interaction with acoustic phonons.
Exciton-exciton scattering.
Charge impurity scattering.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1f shows the first derivative of differential reflectivity for various temperatures in a capped MoS2 ML. What does the similar temperature dependence of the linewidth observed in PL (Fig. 1d) and reflectivity suggest?
choices: Both PL and reflectivity are primarily influenced by defect-bound excitons.
Both PL and reflectivity are dominated by free neutral exciton transitions.
PL is dominated by free excitons while reflectivity is dominated by trapped excitons.
The temperature dependence of linewidth is solely due to changes in the dielectric environment.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2a shows the integrated PL intensity and linewidth as a function of excitation power density. What does the linear relationship between intensity and power density suggest?
choices: The dominant recombination mechanism is non-radiative at low excitation powers.
The PL signal is primarily originating from defect states within the MoS2 ML.
The observed PL signal is dominated by exciton-exciton annihilation processes.
The PL signal originates predominantly from linear recombination of excitons.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2b presents the degree of linear (P_lin) and circular (P_c) polarization as a function of laser power density. What can be inferred from the robust and high degree of circular polarization (P_c ~ 30%)?
choices: Efficient initialization of valley polarization is achieved even at very low excitation power densities.
Valley polarization is strongly dependent on the excitation power density used in the experiment.
The observed valley polarization is a result of strong interactions between excitons in different valleys.
Linearly polarized excitation is more efficient for valley polarization compared to circularly polarized excitation.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2c depicts the chiral optical selection rules for interband optical transitions in MoS2 MLs. What is the significance of these selection rules for valleytronics applications?
choices: They allow for selective population of specific valleys using circularly polarized light, enabling valley-dependent information encoding.
They dictate that only linearly polarized light can be absorbed by MoS2 MLs, limiting their potential for valleytronic devices.
They imply that both valleys are always equally populated regardless of the excitation polarization, hindering valley-selective control.
They are only relevant for interlayer excitons and have negligible impact on intralayer excitons in MoS2 MLs.
